clinical_study.brief_title: Timing of Closure of Patent Foramen Ovale Following Birth
clinical_study.official_title: Timing of Closure of Patent Foramen Ovale and Patent Ductus Arteriosus Following Birth

brief_summary.textblock: It is known that the foramen ovale closes in most infants during the first 6 months of life, however, most of the important papers in the field concentrated on observing infants with murmurs and following those with patent foramen ovale by echocardiography until 6-24 months. The purpose of this study is to observe the natural profile of closure of the foramen ovale and ductus arteriosus for the first 36 hours after birth. This understanding may help to avoid unnecessary treatment and exams for newborns with findings that are natural for their stage of development.

detailed_description.textblock: We will observe the patency and size of foramen ovale five times within the first 36 hours of life. We will also describe the anatomy of the foramen ovale and the septum primum during this time. The direction of flow across the foramen ovale will also be observed. Other cardiac lesions will be checked for as well. We will measure the change in size of the pulmonary arteries and the closure of the ductus arteriosus.

primary_outcome.measure: Patent Foramen Ovale size using 2 echocardiography positions, shunt direction and distance of septum primum to Superior Vena Cava
primary_outcome.time_frame: 2-3 hours after birth, 5-6 hours, 7-8 hours, 12-13 hours and 36 hours

secondary_outcome.measure: Patent Ductus Arteriosus size, shunt direction and the size of the Left Pulmonary Artery, the Right Pulmonary Artery and the Pulmonary Annulus
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 2-3 hours after birth, 5-6 hours, 7-8 hours, 12-13 hours, 36 hours

clinical_study.condition: Closure of the Foramen Ovale and Ductus Arteriosus

arm_group.description: Any healthy term newborn born in Wolfson Medical Center

study_pop.textblock: Population consits of newborn babies born in term and under normal delivery in Wolfson M.C.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- any baby born in term and with normal delivery
Exclusion Criteria:
- sick newborns in need of neonatal intensive care for any medical reason.
- newborns with congenital heart disease except for small, muscular ventricular septal defects
